variant.bodyText: The Albert Thomas Convention Center in Houston, Texas will be the site of the second annual AFIPS Office Automation Conference (OAC) March 23-25, 1981. "Investing in Productivity" is this year's con- ference theme, and over 200 speakers have been scheduled in more than 60 learning sessions. The focus of these sessions will be directed at the way in which automation technologies can be harnessed and integrated to increase productivity and effectiveness of office workers. Sessions will include such topics as Feasibility Studies, Organizational Impact, Systems Architecture, Electronic Mail, Teleconferencing, and State-of-the-Art in Word Processing. For information and registration forms contact:
variant.figure: Ms. Carol Sturgeon AFIPS - OAC - P.O. Box 9658 1815 North Lynn Street - Suite 800 Arlington, Virginia 22209 (703) 558-3613
variant.note: ACL to sponsor two sessions at NCC '81
variant.bodyText: The 1981 National Computer Conference, spon- sored by AFIPS, will be held at McCormick Place in Chicago, May 4-7, 1981. In addition to the technical program consisting of papers, panels, surveys and tuto- rials, there will be a series of one-day professional development seminars and the largest exhibit of com- puter products and services in the world. The use of robots and artificial intelligence will be among the program sessions at the Personal Comput- ing Festival which will be held during the Conference, and personal computing exhibits will appear in the main exhibit area for the first time. ACL will sponsor two sessions at the NCC, organ- ized by a committee consisting of Martha Evens, Jane Robinson, Norm Sondheimer and Don Walker. One is a paper session, chaired by Martha Evens, on the top- ic, "Communicating with Computers in Natural Lan- guage - Current Capabilities," which will have the following three talks:
variant.subsectionHeader: Issues in the Development of Natural Language Front- Ends James Hendler, Thomas Kehler, Paul Michaelis, Brian Phillips, Kenneth Ross and Harry Tennant, Texas Instruments Text-Critiquing with the EPISTLE System: An Author's Aid to Better Syntax Lance Miller, George Heidorn and Karen Jensen, IBM T.J. Watson Research Center Shifting to a Higher Gear in a Natural Language System Bozena Thompson and Frederick Thompson, California Institute of Technology
variant.bodyText: The other ACL session is a panel session, chaired by Norm Sondheimer, on the topic, "Communicating with Computers in Natural Language - Future Promis- es," with the following four participants:
variant.subsectionHeader: Applications for the Handicapped Madeleine Bates, Bolt Beranek and Newman Business Applications Larry Harris, Artificial Intelligence Corp. Military Applications Christine Montgomery, Operating Systems, Inc. Medical Applications Donald Walker, SRI International
variant.bodyText: The ACL will also hold a special one-day meeting in conjunction with the 1981 LSA Winter Meeting in New York City in December. More information about this will appear in later issues of the AJCL.
variant.figure: For further information about NCC '81 contact: Mr. Gerard Chiffriller AFIPS - OAC - P.O. Box 9658 1815 North Lynn Street - Suite 800 Arlington, Virginia 22209 (703) 243-4100
variant.subsectionHeader: Computers and Data Bases in the Humanities and Social Sciences
variant.bodyText: The Fifth International Conference on Computers in the Humanities is scheduled for May 17-20, 1981, in Ann Arbor, Michigan, sponsored by the University of Michigan, Association for Computers in the Hu- manities, and Association for Literary and Linguistic Computing in cooperation with ACM SIGLASH (Language Analysis and Studies in the Humanities). Contributions are invited that present the results of computer-assisted research and creation in the arts. Send inquiries and one-page abstracts before February 15, 1981, to:
variant.affiliation: Richard W. Bailey Department of English The University of Michigan
variant.bodyText: This will be followed immediately by the Third Conference on Data Bases in the Humanities and So- cial Sciences (Joint Conference on Easier and More Productive Use of Computing Systems), May 20-22, also in Ann Arbor, sponsored by the Association for Computers in the Humanities and the University of Michigan. This conference has two facets: the quality of the human interface and the characteristics of data American Journal of Computational Linguistics, Volume 6, Number 3-4, July-December 1980 193 The FINITE STRING Newsletter Announcements base applications. The conference is intended as inte- grating the insights of the social sciences, humanities, computer science, and human factors engineering. Abstracts for papers and panel discussions should be submitted by February 15, 1981, to:
4258 Institute for Social Research The University of Michigan Ann Arbor, Michigan 48106 (313) 763-3482

The ACM Special Interest Groups on Programming Languages and Office Automation will jointly sponsor a Symposium on Text Manipulation, June 8-10, 1981, in Portland, Oregon. This symposium will deal with the variety of tools, techniques and programs that have been developed for creating and manipulating text, whether natural language text or programming lan- guage text. The emphasis is to be on ideas that can be generalized beyond the context in which they were originally developed. The conference chairman is:
variant.table: Paul Abrahams ACM Symposium on Text Manipulation P.O. Box 161 Deerfield, Massachusetts 01342
variant.subsectionHeader: Seventh International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence
variant.bodyText: The Seventh International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence will be held in Vancouver, Brit- ish Columbia, Canada, August 24-28, 1981. Topics of interest include natural language processing, knowl- edge representation, expert systems and cognitive sci- ence. Papers must be submitted to the program com- mittee by March 1, 1981, in one of the following cate- gories: papers (6,000 words max.), communications (1,200 words max.), and programs (500 words max.). Questions about the technical program should be addressed to:
variant.table: Roger C. Schank Program Chairman, IJCAI-81 Department of Computer Science Box 2158 Yale Station Yale University New Haven, Connecticut 06520 (203) 436-0606 General questions about the conference may be addressed to: Pat Hayes General Chairman, IJCAI-81
variant.affiliation: Department of Computer Science Mathematical Sciences Building University of Rochester Rochester, New York 14627
variant.subsectionHeader: British Society for the Philosophy of Science
variant.bodyText: The 1981 Annual Conference of the British Society for the Philosophy of Science will be held at Wivenhoe House, the Eighteenth Century Conference Centre of the University of Essex, September 18-20, 1981. The program will consist of four sessions with speakers, discussants and general discussion. One of these ses- sions will be
variant.subsectionHeader: Consciousness and Machines Yorick Wilks, University of Essex
variant.bodyText: Further details of the conference, registration infor- mation, etc., may be obtained from:
variant.figure: Liaison Officer University of Essex Wivenhoe Park Colchester C04 3SQ, Essex, ENGLAND ACM 1981 Annual Conference
variant.bodyText: The 1981 ACM Annual Conference will be held at the Bonaventure Hotel in Los Angeles, California, November 9-11, 1981, and will feature presentations on a wide variety of topics that are of interest to today's computer professional. The program commit- tee is soliciting contributions in the form of tutorials, proposals for panel discussions, and short technical papers or surveys. Work that addresses areas of prac- tical importance is especially welcome. Technical pa- pers should focus on innovations or recent advances, and should stress the connection between theory and application. Suggested topics include artificial intelli- gence, office automation, data base systems, and per- sonal computing. Four copies of papers (maximum 12 double-spaced pages in length) should be submitted by March 7, 1981, to: ACM '81 - Call for Papers Village Station P.O. Box 24059 Los Angeles, California 90024
variant.subsectionHeader: Workshops on Semantics and Representation of Knowledge being held in New York
variant.bodyText: In February 1980, a series of monthly workshops on the semantics of natural language and issues of representing knowledge was started at the IBM Sys- tems Research Institute in New York City. The work- shops are open to research workers and graduate stu- dents in the fields of artificial intelligence, cognitive psychology, computational linguistics, data base se- mantics, linguistics, philosophy, psycholinguistics, and symbolic logic. Nine meetings were held in 1980 with 17 speakers and about 100 attendees, many of whom came to nearly every session.
variant.page: 194 American Journal of Computational Linguistics, Volume 6, Number 3-4, July-December 1980
variant.bodyText: In the spring of 1981, the following sessions have been scheduled:
variant.subsectionHeader: February 20: Some Psychology of Reasoning Janet Krueger, Department of Psychology, Vassar College Homography in the Memory Lab David Gorfein and Jeanne Viviani,
variant.affiliation: Department of Psychology, Adelphi University
variant.table: March 20: Arc-Pair Grammars Paul Postal, Mathematical Sciences Department, IBM T.J. Watson Research Center
variant.bodyText: Exact dates and topics for the rest of the year have not yet been confirmed, but the following speakers are planning to give talks at the April, May, and June
variant.reference: meetings: David Shaw, Computer Science Department, Columbia University; Martin Ringle, Cognitive Science Studies, Vassar College; S. Jack Odell, Department of Philosophy, University of Maryland, on sabbatical at the /BM Systems Research Institute; and Lance Miller, Computer Sciences Department, IBM T.J. Watson Re- search Centei. Anyone who is interested in speaking or participating in the workshops should send name, address, and a description of research interests to: John F. Sowa IBM Systems Research Institute 205 East 42nd Street New York, New York 10017 (212) 983-7231 Other Conferences The Twenty-Second Computer Society International Conference (COMPCON Spring '81), sponsored by the IEEE Computer Society, will be held at the Jack Tar Hotel in San Francisco, February 23-26, 1981. For further information contact: Sidney Fernbach COMPCON Spring Standing Committee 2020 Research Drive Livermore, California 94550 The 1981 ACM Ccmputer Science Conference will be held at Stouffer's Riverfront Towers in St. Louis, Missouri, February 24-26, 1981. For information contact: John W. Hamblen Computer Science Department University of Missouri - Rolla Rolla, Missouri 65401 (314) 341-4492
variant.bodyText: The second SYSTRAN International Conference will be held at the Canyon Hotel in Palm Springs, Califor- nia, April 12-15, 1981. The theme for this conference will be "Multilingual Communications for the 1980's - Business and Government Requirements." A demon- stration of translation to voice will be included. Fur- ther information can be obtained from:
variant.figure: World Translation Company of Canada, Ltd. 220 Laurier Avenue West Ottawa, Ontario KIP 5Z9, CANADA (613) 563-0137
variant.reference: The Fourth Annual International SIGIR Conference will be held at the Claremont Hotel in Berkeley, Cali- fornia, from May 31 to June 2, 1981, sponsored by ACM SIGIR in cooperation with ASIS and hosted by the School of Library and Information Studies of the University of California. The theme of the conference will be "Theoretical Issues in Information Retrieval." For further information contact: Dr. Jessie Herr Research Libraries Group Stanford University Stanford, California 94305 The Third Annual Meeting of the Society for Schol- arly Publishing will be held at the Golden Gateway Holiday Inn in San Francisco, California, June 1-3, 1981. Further information may be obtained from: Elizabeth C. Fake Society for Scholarly Publishing 2000 Florida Avenue N.W. Washington, D.C. 20009 (202) 638-5970 The Seventh Conference of the Canadian Man- Computer Communication Society, sponsored by the Canadian Man-CCS and the Canadian Image Process- ing and Pattern Recognition Society, will be held in Waterloo, Ontario, June 10-12, 1981. For further information contact: Dr. K. Booth Department of Computer Science University of Waterloo Waterloo, Ontario N2L 3G1, CANADA The Third Annual Meeting of the Cognitive Science Society will be held in Berkeley, California, August 19-21, 1981. Information about the meeting can be obtained from: Robert Wilensky Computer Science Division Department of EECS University of California, Berkeley Berkeley, California 94720 American Journal of Computational Linguistics, Volume 6, Number 3-4, July-December 1980 195
